Solid joint for a normal no thrills breakfast.  Went for my first time this morning.  I places were you can just sidle up to the counter, get your coffee and fire off an order w/o dealing with a menu.  No banana and chutney stuffed french toast here.  Eggs and flap jacks. Like it or leave it.  I like it, and will definitely trek back.  Maybe next time, I tackle The Slinger.

My brother brought me here the night the Bears lost the Super Bowl (I was visiting from New York), so I was slightly inebriated.  Which is the BEST time to go!  If you're sober, you'll notice how The Slinger is pretty much a heart attack on a plate.  Chili, two hamburger patties, eggs, and hash browns...so bad, yet so delicious!  It actually cheered me up!  Once you're done, you get a suprise from the grill man too!  "Don't ask, just eat!" Sidenote:  I went there shortly after moving back to Chicago SOBER.  The Slinger wasn't any less delicious, but the guilt you don't feel when you're drunk didn't allow me to enjoy it as much.

Used to be my secret spot for late night food.........now its just way too packed.  I drive by now and laugh at the idiots who pack in the place and stand around waiting to sit down and eat!!  "huh huh I gotta get a slinger....duh"    The joint is tiny and you think I am gonna stand inside and hover over someone waiting for them to get up so i can eat?  ha, yeah right. If it's late night, you have Garcia's, and even Golden Nugget.   If you don't like those options....GO HOME & GO TO BED!

This place is my savior. It has saved me from self-induced pain after a long night of drinking. It has also kept me up with heartburn, but that was my fault. I do have my precious slinger certificate, and I keep trying to convince Ken and Fernando to add the 'Son of Slinger' on the menu. Picture this: 1 pancake, topped with two over-easy eggs, topped with swiss cheese, topped with hash browns, add a side of bacon, a side of sausage, covered in chili and maple syrup. It may sound awful but it's just delicious.

So this IS called the Diner Grill? Ok, I'll note that because the signs say both!  I miss my old neighborhood the most because of Dinner/Diner Grill. This is the best place to end the night after drinking all night.  OR! The best place to go for breakfast after a night of drinking.  I think that if I end up stumbling out of the Montrose Saloon some night soon, I'll take a cab to Dinner/Diner Grill *and* back just because their cheeseburgers and fries are that awesome. Also, the cooks are hilarious, even if they can be un poco perverted.

Diner Grill...... its 24 hours...... their cheese burger is hot, tasty and cheap (sorry Carol K)........... The Slinger is sure to fill you up! Cash only....... Great when you are driving home after a LONG night in Wicker Park..... I always seem to find a parking spot out front.... Order, eat......outta there..........and I'm outta here. PEACE! I

I moved to North Center a bit ago and never even noticed this place because of the broken Brown Line El. Irving Park finally opened and... WHAT? There is a 24 diner that I was unaware of? Mental note. Though I have never been there after a nigh of drinking, the next morning is always interesting, so I walked over there with a friend and got omelet, hash browns and toast; Let me tell you, it hit the spot for sure, especially in this cold weather.  The only downfall is the price. Maybe I am used to crappier places, but $7.50-8.00 for an omelet and hash browns? Damn you are lucky you are so delicious...

Its 4:30 am. Walk into Diner Grill - Demand a Mickey Mouse Pancake. The cooks will snicker and  create a masterpiece of their own. A penis shaped pancake with a complementry scoop of Ice Cream at the tip. And for the Ladies who like to dance on counters- as long as you ask the cooks- and play a "pop lock and drop it" - its a-okay. The ceiling is a little low but you still do it. The place is great when you need something fill you up after a night of heavy drinking. Not sure what the food tastes like when you are sober- but its great everytime I go.

I lived in Chicago for one year, and I miss it dearly...one of the primary reasons is this fucking greasy spoon. The halfway point between my house and one of my best friend's, I cannot count how many nights we started at the Diner Grill, finished at the Diner Grill, or started AND finished at the Diner Grill. Greasy goodness sober, drunk, or hung over...this place brought me back to my old school Jersey roots when I lived in the Midwest. The internet jukebox obviously causes hilarity to ensue whenever my friends and I would go there, and half the time I walked in there, some kind of death-metal would be blaring from the speakers. And it survived a fire...not even Wayne Manor survived a fire.  But the Pentagon did, as did the Diner Grill.  God Bless America, and God Bless the Diner Grill.

When I first looked at this place I thought complete shit hole, but after stumbling in after a drunken evening and sitting down enjoying a SLINGER, I thought maaaan, this place isn't half bad. The Slinger is a mixture of eggs, cheese, hash browns, two sausage patties, chilli and chilli beans. Thinking about it and then looking at it will make you walk out of the place, because the dish really looks like someone puked it on your plate. If you can finish the concoction you recieve a certificate (I myself am a 3-time winner of the slinger certificate and won twice in head to head competition). Not a whole lot of sitting space, but usually not that crowded on some nights. The grillmen are funny and friendly and they really make you feel welcome. The bathroom is a different story! If you can avoid using it, please do at all costs. All in all, this is a pretty good place to visit after a late, wild night of serious drinking and partying

I refer to this place as "the Dinner Diner Grill" as the sign facing Irving Park says, "Diner Grill" while the sign facing Marshfield says, "Dinner Grill." I'd like to think that when ordering a sign, the owner either wasn't sure what to call the place or perhaps wasn't sure how to spell the choice he wanted. Not wanting to waste his time on such a decision, he said, "Aw fuck it, have it say both!" and then left the room to drink a case of beer and watch the Bears. The internet jukebox in the corner and the weekend post-bar crowd are the only things that detract from the authentic seediness of the joint. Otherwise you really get the feeling that this place hasn't changed much since it opened. As a matter a fact, I don't think Kenny - the paper-hatted, burger-slinging, fry-cook extraordinaire - has so much as changed his shirt since then. The fryer recently went up in flames so for the time being all orders of fries are replaced with hash browns. Your meal, which will be greasy and delicious, will be served on a paper plate and ready for you before you know it. You will pay with cash and if you come in enough, Kenny may pour you a free shot from a $7 bottle of whiskey he keeps under the counter. You will drink this out of a styrofoam cup.  You know that Edward Hopper painting "Nighthawks" (you do, do a Google image search). Take that exact image and make everything a little seedier, the patrons more disheveled, the walls a little dingier and the ambiance a touch grungier. The Diner Grill is a place where unshaven bears of men come to wreck havoc on their stomachs and laugh in the face of obesity.  I anxiously await the day when I'm tanked enough to order and devour "The Slinger". I've got just the place for the certificate on my fridge. Though it will be the pride in my heart that will last forever. This is a good place to go if... you enjoy going to places where eating 1500 calories in a single sitting is rewarded with a piece of paper.
The more things change, the more they remain the same.  Welcome back, Diner Grill.

I beg of you not to tell my boyfriend that I gave Diner Grill 3 stars. Please! He worships this place and still has his first "Slinger Completion" certificate. When we came in with a group of hungry drunken Rugby players, I was eager to see what the hoopla was about. Having stuck to my annual "Sober October" ritual, I was completely coherent and hungry for some good diner style grub. The space is T-I-N-Y with only a few seats at the counter. Get there during peak bar hours, and you'll be greeted with a nice wait. I usually have no problem waiting to be seated, but at 3am, my patience wears thin! Sadly, the food didn't live up to the hype. I LOVE greasy spoons, but the food was so so. I had a burger. It was ok. I wish they served fries, but the hash browns had a nice flavor. Those 3 sentences are the most I can muster about my meal. Naturally, the rest of my group ordered Slingers and woofed them down like they were in an eating contest. As the plates were cleared one was bragging at the speed of consumption vs my boyfriend's boast of taking down the dish with an additional side of bacon. In the end it became painfully obvious that the appeal of Diner Grill was being able to get the nasties goopiest meal possible to kill the drunken munchies in a North Side institution. We had a good time during our short (eat and get out - people are waiting for your seat!) visit, and the Touch Tunes machine made for some great singalongs to some horrible songs. Based on atmosphere alone, Diner Grill might get the nod on another night in another month. However, that night, sober Alexis spent her time in Diner Grill wishing she'd gone to a few blocks over to (the still delicious without drinking) Wrigleyville's Dog.  One thing that really bothered me was despite the friendly well oiled service, the man assisting the cook was also handling the money. Call me a germaphobe, but I dislike seeing someone count money before they put food on my plate. Would I have been this perceptive if I were drunk? Probably not. Will I let myself return after drinking? Most Definitely.  Singing Celine Dion at the top of my lungs while eating a greasy mess of slop always sounds good after putting back a few.

They should have pocketed the fire insurance proceeds, and sold the place off to a developer. I went today for its first day open since the fire.  Exorbitant prices for the same slime as before. Before part of the charm of the slime food was that it wasn't too expensive. Now,  you can get far better food almost anywhere else for the same prices, or less.

Every time I eat here- I get diarrhea.  So why do I keep coming back? I'll tell you why. Because it's good.  It's very, VERY good. I have a refridgerator covered in 'I Ate The Slinger' certificates and it's open at all hours of the day and night(The Diner, not my fridge).   Although they are currently undergoing some remodeling, I intend to stock up on Immodium b/c I can't wait to go back again. I love you Diner Grill.  Don't ever leave me.

So a little late night snack turned into a monster mound of greasy, fried goodness. What can I say? I was curious. The famous Slinger was everything I hoped it would be, and I was horrified that I packed it all in. I think the cooks were astonished too. If you're going to order this dish, my only suggestion is to sub sausage patties for the hamburger, or if you prefer hamburger ask for bacon on top.    Diner Grill is greasy spoon perfection. It's dirty but not over the top. The cooks are surly but humorous And the food is swathed with the right amount of grease. The Slinger is the most expensive menu item at $8.50, but it's large enough to share with a couple of people.  Stumble over there after a long night of drinking. You won't be sorry.

Yelp Event. Free Beers. Holiday Club. More Beers. Closing Time. Say Bye To Friends. Start Walking. Stomach Growling. Behold: Diner Grill. Crowded. Loud. Smells Delicious. Bacon on Grill. Grab Seats. Order Burger with Bacon. Fries. More Bacon on Grill. Eats. Awesomeness.

Tastes like a full size Krystal burger, as a side note Krystal burgers are delicious and may contain small amounts of heroin(the only explanation for being able to eat 8-10 in 3 minutes) .  I love this place its nice simple and convenient and the food is made right in front of your eyes as you talk over the weather or baseball with the friendly staff.  Did I mention the prices are low?  Forget this for only your late night drinking greasy spoon, its also great for lunch or a quick meal.

This place is too good to be thought of as a mere hangover cure!  Eggs + toast + trailer = way more fun than any fancy schmancy brunch joint.  If you're going to eat grease, do it right. Do the Diner.

OK, it is time to set the record straight. Yes, the Slinger is a sight to behold, and an adventure to eat (or is the adventure after you eat it?). I've got my certificate and earned every bit of it. And from all the reviews, the Slinger is well known and has earned its due. However, to me the real prize of the Diner Grill is an item that I've not seen listed on the menu board. Several years ago when Rich was still the cook, I was contemplating aloud what I should eat to help soak up my evening's bender (no Slinger on this fateful night). Me: "Hmm, a bacon cheeseburger sure sounds good. But the garbage omelet is always really good too. Eggs always hit the spot at this hour." Rich: "Why don't you just have both?" Me: "Really? I can do that??"  Rich: "Sure. These Irish guys (points to end of counter) do it all the time" So I offer for your consideration what Rich recommended to me on that fateful night - the bacon double cheeseburger with fried egg. Now it is not unusual to find establishments that will put an egg on your burger. I've sampled them all over. However, there is something special about the Diner's take on this that sets it apart. Perhaps it is the grease. Maybe it is how the fried egg is never overdone and the yolk pours all over the burger. The pickles are a nice touch. Certainly the bacon helps. As do the thin burger patties that allow me to go for full artery clogging action by making it a double. I'm pretty sure "Elvira" by the Oak Ridge Boys was playing that night/morning also.  I don't know why the concept seemed so unusual to me on that particular night, but that is all I've ordered ever since. And while I give it 5 stars, don't be fooled - it is a diner. In a trailer. This is not Spiaggia. I do wish the crappy jukeboxes that were on the counter were still there instead of the new fancy one on the far wall. But aside from that, the Diner Grill remains a standout, quintessential late night diner food. Thank you Rich.

Order the Slinger = Order Charmin.  Order the Slinger = Order a satisfying and delicious artery clogger. Order the Slinger = Order enlightment Bring cash and order the Slinger. Enjoy this no-frills diner.

I follow yelp reviews: If it is recommended by either Oscar the Death Cat or Max Power I'm heading out at warp-speed and will never be disappointed.  This was a lot of fun. It was dinner and theater my friend... The cook was filled with witty one-liners and hearty banter, the food so gloriously greasy I should've scheduled an angioplasty yesterday and despite my rather conspicuous yuppie-dink-ness- I felt charmed.  That's CHARMED, not wasted. Hence, why I was not brave enough to face the Slinger (despite colorful description and recommendations) . Some day.... until then, ask about the album- yes the album filled with photos of the Slinger-conquerers. You won't be sorry- in fact, you will be forced to laugh!

I love everything about this place. The short order cooks are my heroes, always watching Dr. Phil or Bulls games. They have some weird ass regulars, which you know that's cool. And the food battles for awesomeness with a southern love of mine, Waffle House. Go ahead and go wild and get the slinger. I prefer mine without chili, so I never get the certificate.

Can we please look at the fact that Diner Grill has signs hanging up toting that the slinger will, without a doubt, give you terrible diarrhea. About a month ago I found myself in the diner at roughly 4am, prime slinger ordering hour, and shit was going off! (Note: Yes, I realize this place always gets rowdy in the wee hours of the morning, but there was something special in the air.) Some piece of trash older gentleman ordered a slinger, a stack of pancakes, french toast, a side of bacon, a cheeseburger, and coffee. He refused to sit at the counter, instead choosing to stand in the back corner, scowling at anyone who came near him or his food. I hope he's dead now. Meanwhile, some young hooligans out on the town had wandered in for some slingers of their own. A guy in his early 20s requested that his slinger be made up of the table scraps of three half eaten slingers left on the counter. His wish was granted and the chef scraped the remains on one plate, threw a few dollops of butter on top and off he went. His meal ended up being on the house; talk about good service! Health code be damned, they'll give you what you want. When I left with my friend we both threw up in the snow on the side of the building. It was without a doubt one of the finest dining experiences I've ever had the pleasure of knowing.
i did it! i..finally...con....quered.....the.......sling.........zzzzzzzzzzzzzz...........

We refer to this place as simply, "the diner." I love it. I love the slinger. If you are going in knowing you won't finish it, you can try a slinger without the chili and still put it down pretty easily. To be perfectly honest, this is one of those complete dives that is truly a diamond in the rough. It is the perfect after the bar place to grab some food and have a few more laughs before the night is over.  Positives: Mello Yellow to drink Slingers white bread with your order the cook is hilarious juke box for tunes (I recommend playing Johnny Cash's "Ring of Fire" on a continuous loop.) Negatives: bathroom is very disgusting cash only juke box - the place lost a little of its charm when it went all digital. I remember handing the cook $5 once and telling him that I didn't want to hear anything except Ring of Fire while I was there.

This place is sooo cool!  It does look a little sketchy from the outside but whatever it's all about the experience you get inside the diner.   I stick with the $2.35 grilled cheese and a choc milkshake.  Yum!   Ask to see the binder filled with pics of people that have successfully eaten the Slinger...it's full of weirdos :)

I've been going to the Diner for the past couple of years and introducing it to many of my unsuspecting drunk friends who think that they can finish a Slinger, but just end up staring at a half-finished plate thinking, "what have I done?" A couple of reasons/examples why I like this place: -Ken, the chef/order taker, is a guy that takes a lot of verbal shit, but spits it right back in a non-Weiner Circle way.  Specifically, I'm in the place around 3 a.m. or so one morning and a couple of  "dudes" come in to the place (think Alumni Club - Schaumburg type dudes) looking for some grub.  While ordering,  they ask Ken what kind of cheese are on the cheeseburgers.  His simple response, a Carson-like blank stare down the bar line and a "you're kidding."  Personally, I think the dudes should've gotten a certificate banning them for life from the place.  Alas, they were serverd, government cheese and all. -On one of my more impressive 6:30 a.m. night outs I came here with two Diner newbies, one of whom was a Packers fan.  The Bears were playing the Packers that morning so the cook made a pancake that he thought was fit for a Packer fan.  As far as the shape of the Packer Pancake goes, let's just say it rhymed with "rock n'halls" and required a whip cream topping. Now, why I took off one star from my rating: -The place is losing a bit of its old-old-old school charm.  I walked in earlier this year and saw the enormous jukebox, bose speaker system and re-done duct work and thought WTF?  Add those changes to the word getting out on this place and you have a recipe for burnout.  Still, I asked Ken about the changes and he just shook his head, took a drag from his cig and finished making me a bacon sandwich.  Classic................

quintessential diner straight out of an old movie.  traincar style greasy spoon with all counter service.  CLASSIC!  perfect for a 4am meal after the bars close though i shudder at the thought of slinger-rhea... try it if you dare!
Cute place to eat breakfast foods!  Overall, good food and good service!

after ten cat we went on a noble quest to conquer the slinger. he finished first even though i hit the half way point way before him...about 75% though i was going to give up...but i even had a vegan cheering me on so i couldn't stop.  i ate my slinger. i got a certificate.  i vomited by a tree and road my bike home. the diner grill is not for the feint of heart...i salute you cook ken!

This is a conditional review. This place is only 4 stars when you're drunk and it's after midnight. You MUST be good and drunk!!! The slinger's should be called the block artery special or something like that. I think if you enjoy the ER, it's a good option for you.  I personally like the way the cook will cook the crap out of the hashbrowns if you ask him to. I ask every time I order those things and no one actually cooks the crap out fo them. The Diner does.  If you can't find a seat too friggin bad. If you don't like a lot of grease, boo hoo for you, don't go. But if you're hankering for some grease accompanied by a slice of white bread, then this is your place.  I highly recommend spending several hours in the long room, then crossing the street (look both ways, hold hands) and eating here. It's a good combo for a night out.

The first time I came in here, I needed bacon, and lots of it. My three orders of delicious, greasy bacon were ready very quickly, and they were so cheap! I was sold, and now I come in here frequently for double cheeseburgers, corned beef hash, slingers, and hash browns. The slinger is intimidating, but if you get it without chili, it's actually really good. If you finish one, you get a certificate! Also, my roommate refers to the cuisine here as "meef." I don't think you get any better than that.

The Slinger and my toilet are not friends.  I had to try it.  It's not bad but its not great.   The place is old school cool.  Haven't had it in a while since I'm a fat guy waiting to happen.  The Diner's got the typical "give you a heart attack" menu items.  Above all else the place definitely has character.  Bottom Line:  If I'm in the area, boozin, late night, and got the munchies, this is where i'm headed.

One of my favorite diners of all time. I have been here many times, and everything I've had has been nothing but the Tastiest of the Tasty. Late night is when this joint is hoppin', and you might have a brief wait while you ponder all those tequila shots you did that night. The cheeseburgers are one of my faves--make sure you get a double; the single just isn't the same. Hash browns are the best, order them with onions and cheese.  For fun, have a look at the photo albums. One of these days, I'll win me one of those Slinger certificates.

After reading other reviews for this place I can say I've had greaser foods in other diners. The food here really wasn't that bad. I had the Ham & Eggs, and thought that I would be having just Ham & Eggs, but little did I know Ham & Eggs comes with Hashbrowns, and Toast. Bonus! Realize that the music here is from a Touch Tunes machine so sometimes there can be Hip/Hop, Country, and any other genre you can think of. If you don't like all types of music than don't go here. But good food and good music make this place rock! Remember also this place doesn't take CC's so make sure you bring a ten'er with you!

This place is delicious.  Now, I'm not sure what it tastes like sober (I'm sure it's not that great).  I saw someone eat a slinger there once and quite frankly I'm really not the same.  I stick with your typical eggs, hasbrowns, bacon, any other greasy goodness that will make me puke two hours later.

LOUD jukebox, rowdy drunk crowd, greasy food and super cheap.  It's really just what you're looking for in a 3 am dining experience.  The cheeseburger is surprisingly tasty for a frozen patty and the fries aren't too greasy.  As for the Slinger... I haven't tried it but you have to love a food item advertised with drawings of characters in various states of GI distress.

Could not be more of a greasy spoon unless the building itself was actually shaped like a spoon, covered in lard.    I have tried the slider and I must say: it is an experience that stays with you long after you have finished.  Some good memories and some bad but no regrets. THE place to go when its late at night, you are on the verge of bedspins, and only a greasy meal can bring you back.

Grease, grease, grease, salt, and grease. Back when I lived a couple blocks away, I made the mistake of stopping in here. Hey, I like greasy spoon diner food as much as the next guy. Well, OK, maybe not. I've seen some of the "next guys." But I do enjoy the occasional greasy little delight. I got an omelet and some hash browns, and man oh man. Grease city. Actually, I'd say a thriving grease metropolis. Complete with grease suburbs.  I felt sick the next day. I never went back.
This is my favorite cheeseburger in the city. So good! Best consumed late at night after hitting the bars.

You know, I actually forgot this place exists!  It came up as a search result for another diner and I was immediately nostalgic and thought "I need to go there tonight!".  I have not been there in a while, but everythign I ever ate there was great!  Though, haha, I just remembered why I stopped eating there; I went vegetarian.  If I were still carniverous I would be there now.  Great fake rude/charismatic, fun staff.  Not in the obnoxious affected Ed Debevic's way, in the down to earth "Yeah yeah, we've seen your type before" calls you "doll" because that's just how they are, staff.  At least they were...

I just saw my first Slinger today.  Wow.  It disgusts me how they fit that much food onto one plate, in one sloppy mess, and still make it come out delicious.  The three other guys with me all struggled across the finish line and had stomach aches as we walked back to the car. If you finish a slinger, they give you a certificate.

A friend and neighbor affectionately calls this place the Dinner Diner because (contrary to the current photo) one side of the sign says Diner and the other says Dinner!   I concur with my fellow reviewers; you can't beat this greasy dive after a long night at a nearby watering hole.

Get to this place before gentrification forces it out of business! Back in my younger days we load up on weiss beer and jager shots at Lashett's before heading here for a drunken feast. As you could imagine, you would not want to be around us the next morning. Everything is great here for that late-night purpose of filling your gut with starch, protein and grease. My favorities are the grilled ham and cheese sandwich (ham of the bone!), cheeseburger and chili washed down with a bottomless cup of hot coffee. Just beware the bathroom here might be "out of order" when you need it the most.

Sometimes known around the hood as Decapitation Diner, since in '89 one of the cooks was decapitated by a hoodlum. Now take a good look at that ham on the bone sitting on the counter.... I love a place where the only vegetable to be found is in the ketchup bottle and they make no apologies for it.  Oh yea, they do have some of the whitest lettuce I've ever seen for BLTs.  There is no place greasier this side of town. And that's not necessarily a bad thing. If you've been slamming them back all night you probably aren't worried about your clogged arteries anyway. Try the slinger if you dare. There is nothing to sop up a tummy full of alcohol like one of these plates. The ambience is what is special here. There is a smoking section (the last three out of twelve stools at the counter) and the cooks are almost always entertaining. Diner Grill becomes an old man counter in the daytime and  when the bars close it is usually packed with a younger set.  Diner Grill is dining like your grandpa did after he fixed a dozen toilets in the neighborhood. Burgers and eggs and flapjacks done the way they used to be made before we gave a damn about our bodies.

I love this place!  I have never been here while sober, but I think that's the point.  Any place that uses those plastic plates and has their cooks cook right in front of you, has to have good food right?  The eggs and the hashbrowns and the random people at Diner Grill...

One word: Slinger. It consists of a plate lined with hash browns, on top of which sits two burger patties w/ cheese, two fried eggs atop the burgers, and the entire thing covered in chili. And the best part? They give you a certificate if you finish it, signed by the cook. I had to get that certificate.  So I went there after a party around 2AM and of course I crushed it.  I could still taste the chili in the morning when I woke up. I have also been here for burgers and they are good n greasy. I highly recommend this place when drunk, it might be a bit riskier when sober.

I finally made it to the Diner Grill after a few drinks.  We showed up there before the bars let out, so we pretty much had the place to ourselves.  The guys behind the counter were talking about how crazy the place gets after bar time, and gearing themselves up for it.  The food here is super cheap, and good.  You can sit right in front of the grill and watch them do their work.  Their jukebox has quite an array of choices, from Willie Nelson to The Supremes to Red Hot Chili Peppers to Ricky Martin.  My friend and I were wondering about the big red words "Slinger" on the menu, but didn't ask about it.  After reading this, part of me really wants to try it, but at the same time, my brain and stomach are screaming "NO!!".  Maybe next time I'll challenge a friend to take it on. Avoid the bathroom here at all costs!  It was probably the worst that I've seen, this side of India.  At one point, I almost felt like I was in an outhouse with the chilly breeze coming through the vent...The diner itself is fairly clean, but there was a smell reminiscent of a house that was home to an old lady and maybe a couple of cats in existence.

Hands down my favorite post bar diner..... This place is classic, not much has changed since it was first built thats for sure.  The same two guys pretty much work the place together and as long as you're not a drunk idiot they are pretty nice and talkative.  Slingeria is worth it, brave the warning sign and go for it.  Everything else is solid breakfast diner food for a really low price.

OK, what others have said is true- this is a great late-night, soak up the booze in your gut spot.  I've been going there a long time, and not much has changed- thank God!  Things to do at the Diner Grill: 1.  Order a slinger- Don't read on if you want to be suprised at the recipe...   Otherwise, take a plate, cover with hashbrowns, top with three cheeseburger patties, top those with three fried eggs, top that all with a big scoop of chili.  Complete and ask for your certificate to prove it! 2.  If Marty the grill cook still works there- ask to see his baby picture- you won't regret it. 3.  Make friends- everybody there is in the same boat as you, quit being so uptight and learn something! 4.  Avoid any secret hot-sauce they may make availible to you- it'll hurt the next day coming out more than it will going in... 5. Avoid getting run over if you have to cross Irvg Pk while drunk in the middle of the night!

This place epitomizes the word 'diner.'  It's a simple yet wonderful set-up: one counter, one menu, and one working counter top jukebox.  On the first visit, we played 'Rhinestone Cowboy,' which induced a few crazy looks from the regulars.  I've behaved myself since.  The Grill is open 24/7, but the place really starts bumping after the bars close.   If you're craving CHEAP, greasy food that you can chow down on without feeling guilty, come here.  The burgers are only $1.75, and they toast the buns!   I watched someone actually finish a Slinger (an inexplicable concoction) on Saturday night, which was an impressive feat, and now my boyfriend wants the challenge.  I think I'll avoid his bathroom for 24 hours afterwards.  Speaking of bathrooms, don't go in the one here.  As divey as the grill looks like from the counter seats, it's much worse in the loo.  But that's what makes this place so damn cool. Bottom line: come here and feel like a true local at this classy Chicago establishment.

The king of all greasy spoon. It ain't pretty, but you won't leave hungry. Open 24/7, this is a perfect post drinking locale. The first time I ever walked in here, there was an old cardboard pizza tray taped to the wall with the words "Slinger $7.50 don't ask-just eat", ominously scrawled on it. I did as instructed and was not disapointed. Nor will you be if you make your way to the Diner Grill for a Slinger.
